influenza  and  severe  acute  respiratory  syndrome  (SARS), 
dengue, and HIV/AIDS, which are facilitated by increased market

Impact and Outcome 

 

Regional  cooperation  in  CDC  is  justified  if  benefits  exceed  what 
countries  acting  on  their  own  can  achieve.  In  CDC,  the  rationale 
for  regional  cooperation  can  be  broken  down  into  four  broad 
categories,  namely:  (i)  transmission  of  communicable  diseases, 
(ii)  technology  transfers,  (iii)  economies  of  scale  and  greater 
leverage, and (iv) regional public goods for health. 
 
CDC  and  health  systems  in  general  have  developed  in  relative 
isolation. International boundaries reinforced national approaches 
to  health  systems  and  disease  control  in  the  “pre-globalization” 
era,  when  borders  barred  the  movement  of  people  and  goods. 
However,  in  recent  years,  globalization  has  transformed  borders 
from  barriers  to  bridges,  and  this  transformation  has  shifted 
attention to cross-border matters that localities have in common.  
 
The  emergence  in  the  GMS  of  SARS  and  avian  influenza  have 
demonstrated  that  the  economic  impact  from  these  diseases 
amounts  to  billions  of  dollars  through  declining  tourism,  reduced 
flows  of  foreign  investment,  and  export  restrictions  on  livestock 
and  animal  products.  A  human  avian  influenza  pandemic  may 
cause millions of deaths and an economic meltdown. To enhance 
national  economic  and  health  security,  epidemics  must  be 
contained  at  their  source  and  their  potential  spread  in  the  region 
minimized. This will require strong regional efforts for CDC. 
 
The revised IHR of WHO, approved in May 2005, will serve as the 
new legal framework for actions to prevent the spread of disease 
internationally.  Under  the  new  IHR,  countries  will  be  expected  to 
report  any  public  health  threat.  They  will  establish  and  maintain 
minimum  core  surveillance  and 
to 
successfully implement  the global health security, epidemic alert, 
and response strategy. 
 
Regional  economic  developments,  emerging  diseases  and  their 
economic impact, and high-level political commitment to attaining 
MDGs  have  generated  strong  support  for  regional  cooperation 
across health sectors. The current GMS setting favors a regional 
approach  to  CDC  that  can  significantly  improve  the  health  of  the 
poor in the CLV countries.  
 
 
The overall anticipated impact of the GMS Regional CDC Project 
is  to  contain  the  spread  of  epidemic  diseases  at  local  level  and 
reduce  the  burden  of  common  endemic  diseases  in  the  CLV 
countries  by  about  15%  in  the  targeted  provinces,  and  more  for 
certain specific infections. This will help these countries progress 
toward  their  health-related  MDGs  for  2015  of  reducing  the  child 
mortality  rate  and  containing  the  spread  of  HIV/AIDS  and  other 
infections.

The  expected  project  outcomes  are  (i)  timely  and  adequate 
control  of  epidemics  that  are  likely  to  have  a  major  impact  on

Activities  under  the  Project  are  pro-poor,  focusing  on  PHC  and 
community-based  activities  in  priority  provinces.  Women  and 
children will be the major beneficiaries of community interventions. 
Priority  will  be  given  to  CDC  in  remote  areas  including  border 
provinces where many ethnic groups and the poorest reside.

Procurement 

 

ADB-financed  goods  and  services  will  be  procured  according  to 
ADB’s  Guidelines for  Procurement  and  the  relevant  laws  in  each 
country.  However,  if  there  is  any  inconsistency  between  ADB’s 
requirements  and  the  national  laws,  ADB’s  requirements  will 
prevail.  Equipment  will  be  procured  through  (i)  international 
competitive  bidding  for  contracts  worth  at  least  $1  million; 
(ii) international shopping for contracts worth at least $100,000 but 
less  than  $1  million  for  the  Governments  of  Cambodia  and  Lao 
PDR,  and  at  least  $350,000  but  less  than  $1  million  for  the 
Government  of  Viet  Nam;  and  (iii) local  competitive  bidding  or 
direct  purchase  for  items  valued  at  less  than  $100,000  for  the 
Governments of Cambodia and Lao PDR, and less than $350,000 
for  the  Government  of  Viet  Nam.  The  procurement  of  equipment 
and  supplies  will  be  managed  by  each  EA,  which  may  delegate 
this task to IAs for items valued at less than $20,000 in Lao PDR 
and Cambodia, and $50,000 in Viet Nam. 
 
The  Project  will  provide  for  238  person-months  of  international 
and  1,176  person-months  of  national  consulting  services.  Of  the 
international  consultants,  the  regional  project  coordinator,  the 
health  system  development  expert,  and  the  HIV/AIDS  chief 
technical  adviser  will  be  engaged  by  ADB  as 
individual 
consultants  for  a  total  of  68  person-months  according  to  ADB’s 
Guidelines  on  the  Use  of  Consultants.  International  experts  for 
surveillance  and  response,  outbreak  preparedness,  virology, 
dengue  control,  control  of  endemic  diseases,  legislation,  and 
health  information  system  will  be  contracted  for  a  total  of  170 
person-months by WHO as implementing agency according to its 
rules and regulations for administrative procedures and practices. 
ADB-funded experts engaged by WHO must first be approved by 
ADB  and  MOH.  Domestic  consultants  will  be  engaged  as 
individual  consultants  by  each  MOH  according  to  procedures 
acceptable to ADB. 
     
The  Project  will  help  improve  the  health  of  targeted  populations 
and thereby increase their productivity, and help progress toward 
the health-related MDGs. The Project will improve prevention and 
control of communicable diseases, intergovernmental cooperation 
in  containing  and  eliminating  diseases,  and  also  contribute  to 
strengthening national health systems.  
 
Activities  under  the  Project  are  targeted  toward  the  poor  in 
general  and  those  living  in  remote  locations  including  border 
areas,  where  many  ethnic  groups  and  the  most  poor  reside. 
Women  and  children  will  be  the  major  beneficiaries  of  these 
community-level interventions.

The  economic  benefits  of  the  Project  will  come  from  (i)  helping 
prevent major epidemics; (ii) productivity gains from an increased 
lifespan  and  reduced  mortality;  (iii) productivity  gains 
from 
improved  achievements  in  education,  especially  through  less 
absenteeism  and  reduced  dropout  rates;  and  (iv)  public  and 
private savings in health expenditures, including indirect costs.  
 
The  Project  has  some  technical  risks  in  the  effectiveness  of 
control  measures,  in  particular  for  dengue  and  community-based 
surveillance in general. These technical risks will be mitigated by 
partnering  with  WHO,  hiring  more  national  staff  to  build  local 
capacity, 
community 
involvement.  Institutional  networking  and  regional  collaboration 
will also help strengthen the implementation capacity of provinces. 
 
Previous ADB projects showed project management to be critical 
to  achieving  results.  Each  coordinating  IA  will  have  a  project 
management  unit,  which  will  be  supported  by  existing  project 
administrative  capacity  in  each  MOH  in  areas  like  planning, 
procurement, financial management, monitoring, and reporting.    
 
Regional  cooperation  is  known  to  require  considerable  front-end 
costs  with  low  immediate  returns  because  of  an  “incubation 
period.”  However,  these  costs  should  be  offset  by  substantial 
benefits  from  regional  disease  control,  technology  transfer,  and 
strengthened national commitment for health sector development, 
all of which will have long-term value across the region. ADB will 
need  to  provide  substantial  support  for  regional  cooperation  and 
ensure that this becomes fully institutionalized in terms of budget, 
staff, responsibility, and authority in the ministries.

Nature  of  communicable  disease  transmission:  Communicable  diseases  are 
transmitted  by  people,  vectors,  food,  and  elements  throughout  a  particular 
geographic region irrespective of national borders.

share  experiences  and  knowledge  about  health  policies,  system  design,  and 
disease  control,  and  apply  lessons  learned.  These  technology  transfers  also 
facilitate greater consistency, clarity, and transparency among countries in CDC 
and other health matters. 

Economies  of  scale  and  greater  leverage:  Regional  cooperation  helps  to 
achieve  economies  of  scale  for  more  efficient  resource  allocation,  e.g.,  sharing 
design  work,  testing,  expertise,  and  procurement.  Also,  participating  countries 
can acquire greater leverage in attracting donor funding by aggregating particular 
underfunded endemic diseases.

Cambodia, 29% in the Lao PDR, and 56% in Viet Nam, another area of concern.

20. 
Emerging Diseases. Outbreaks of newly emerging diseases such as SARS in 2003 and 
AI in 2004 and 2005 have so far had little impact on health in the region, but could have vastly 
more  devastating  effects.  The  case  fatality  rate  for  SARS  is  around  10%  and  for  human  AI 
about 50%. As of the end of May 2005, 50 people in Viet Nam had died from AI, or 80% of all 
deaths  in  the  region.  Cambodia  has  had  four  deaths  in  Kampot  province.  However,  scientists 
indicate that the AI virus may mutate or reassort into another virus that spreads in humans like 
an ordinary flu virus. This could cause a global pandemic with millions of deaths in the region. 
   
21. 
These  emerging  diseases,  even  with  limited  health  impact,  have  major  economic 
consequences. SARS slowed economic growth by reducing tourism and communication. GDP 
in the region could have declined by 0.2–1.8 percentage points if SARS had persisted for one 
economic quarter, and, GDP in the individual countries could have fallen by 0.5–4.0 percentage 
points if it had gone on for two quarters.7  While the CLV countries do not have a major poultry 
export industry like Thailand, AI has probably reduced GDP by about 0.5% in Viet Nam.8 More 
importantly,  it  has  had  a  major  impact  at  the  local  level  on  poor  backyard  farmers  and  wet 
markets. Viet Nam has culled almost a quarter of its national poultry stock. A human pandemic 
may cause an economic meltdown.   
 
22. 
The fast spread of these diseases and their potential consequences highlight the need 
for regional collaboration in CDC. Such a strategy must entail the strengthening of surveillance 
and response systems from community-level workers detecting outbreaks to laboratory facilities 
and  provincial  and  national  response  centers.  Cooperation  across  the  health  and  agriculture 
sectors  is  important  for  AI.  AI  requires  better  poultry  biosecurity  and  vaccination,  improved 
preparedness  and  response  of  public  and  private  services  including  quarantine  arrangements 
and medicines, and risk profiling and monitoring the spread and genotype of the virus in hosts. 
The  ministries  of  agriculture  in  the  region  are  performing  animal  surveillance  with  assistance 
from  the  Food  and  Agriculture  Organization.  Laboratory  conditions  for  the  cultivation  of  the  AI 
virus in the national animal health laboratories are substandard and pose a biohazard.

These  diseases,  increasingly  being  referred  to  as  neglected  endemic  diseases,  are  often

common problems.

2. 

Vulnerable Populations 

30.  Mobile Populations. A priority in the GMS has been facilitating connectivity among the 
member countries through the provision of transport infrastructure. Greater connectivity results 
in higher flows of people and goods across borders, bringing both benefits and consequences. 
One  of  the  most  problematic  consequences  is  the  spread  of  communicable  diseases  such  as 
sexually  transmitted  infections  and  HIV/AIDS  as  construction  workers,  traders,  transportation 
providers, laborers, and service women move into other areas. Busy border crossing areas tend 
to have among the highest prevalence rates of HIV/AIDS and other communicable diseases. 
 
Remote  Populations.  Populations  residing  in  remote  locations  including  border  areas

Region, people may have to travel more than 25 kilometers on foot to a health post. Both public 
and private sector health-care provision decreases as population density falls, as providers find 
it  difficult  to  work  in  these  places.  Outreach  teams  find  it  difficult  to  reach  remote  villages, 
resulting in lower coverage of immunization and other preventive services in these communities. 
Quarantine stations located at borders can help increase coverage for local populations.

3. 

Challenges in National Health Systems  

34. 
The ultimate purpose of health sector development is to develop a health system that is 
appropriate to a country’s needs and resources, including those related to infectious diseases. 
CDC has to be an integral part of the health system, and indeed bring about positive changes in 
the health system as experienced with the HIV/AIDS control program in Cambodia. There are 
many  generic  issues  in  the  health  system  that  affects  CDC,  including  human  resource 
constraints,  the  management  of  health  services,  and  affordability  and  financing  of  health 
services.  CDC  must  also  cope  with  several  specific  challenges  including  (i)  integration  of 
disease control programs in PHC; (ii) staff constraints for preventive care; (iii) standard setting 
and regulation for CDC, in particular for drugs and for private sector regulation; and (iv) regional 
surveillance and response.  
 
35. 
The  health  systems  in  the  three  countries  feature  a  dichotomy  between  preventive 
programs, usually managed centrally, and provincial health services focusing on treatment. The 
countries lack a comprehensive approach to health system development; as a result, there are 
coordination  problems  and  inefficiencies  in  the  health  system.  Current  donor  funding 
mechanisms amplify this situation such that periodic ad hoc and unsustainable investments are 
made  in  particular  programs  or  disease  interventions,  to  the  extent  that  these  also  undermine 
other  services.  Of  critical  importance  in  the  CLV  countries  is  the  development  of  competent 
provincial health planning, budgeting, management, and monitoring capacity, with the provinces 
having  responsibility  and  authority  for  health  sector  performance,  including  preventive 
programs. 
 
36. 
In all three countries, there is insufficient training and skills in epidemiology among the 
health  staff  who  are  responsible  for  disease  programs.  Therefore,  the  countries  tend  to 
participate  mainly  in  nationally  organized  activities.  A  challenge  is  to  decentralize  CDC 
management  to  the  provinces,  and  reduce  overlap  in  training,  laboratory  services,  and 
supervision.  Such  problems  have  arisen  in  part  because  of  the  lack  of  comprehensive  and 
coordinated planning.

Although  the  extensive  surveillance  network  covers  all  levels  down  to  the  commune 
health  centers,  the  coverage  and  functioning  of  the  surveillance  and  response  systems  need

4. 

Shortage of Regional Public Goods 

38. 
RPGs receive less attention than global public goods and national public goods, despite 
the fact that RPGs can help attain global and national public goods. In particular, rates of return 
on  regional  investments  are  often  higher  than  individual  country  investments  and  reduce  high 
costs for smaller economies. This applies equally to RPGs in the health sector. 
 
39. 
Clear  gaps  in  RPGs  related  to  health  exist  within  the  Association  of  Southeast  Asian 
Nations  (ASEAN)  and  the  GMS  countries.  First,  there  is  no  comprehensive  regional  health 
information system. Several attempts at regional data and information sharing have been made 
(such  as  ASEAN  Disease  Surveillance.net,  MBDSP,  Asian  Collaborative  Training  Network  for 
Malaria  Web  site,  ADB,  and  WPRO);  none  of  these  has  so  far  achieved  a  satisfactory 
information  database.  Sharing  of  health  information  will  require  capacity  building  and  also 
confidence building among the governments. Research with a regional perspective is minimal. 
Research related to mobility across borders is particularly important for HIV/AIDS. 
 
40. 
Aid agencies often prefer to invest in country-focused programs because of the need to 
establish ownership and the relative ease of arranging lending and grants with a single country. 
Broader-scale  health  initiatives  by  the  key  multilateral  institutions  tend  to  be  global  in  scope 
instead of responding to particular regional needs and solutions. These global initiatives prevail 
over regional ones despite the complexities involved in implementing them worldwide, and they 
tend  to  lose  focus  on  the  “weak  links”  (i.e.,  countries  with  limited  capacities)  that  reduce  the 
overall effectiveness of global health initiatives. 
 
41. 
The  current  setting  appears  in  need  of  regional  collaboration  in  CDC.  WHO  is  revising 
the  IHR.  The  forthcoming  revisions  will  provide  member  countries  with  a  common  reference 
point to prevent global health threats and to coordinate international responses to those threats. 
An  important  element  will  be  regional  capacity  building.  The  recent  epidemics  have  created 
more political will to exchange information, harmonize quality standards, and learn key lessons 
from  one  another.  Additionally,  a  major  landmark  was  achieved  in  2003  when  the  six  GMS 
ministers of health signed an agreement to share information as part of the MBDSP financed by 
the  Rockefeller  Foundation.  Progress  in  ASEAN  and  GMS  has  created  a  strong  institutional 
framework for regional collaboration beyond trade and infrastructure issues.  
 
42. 
Regional cooperation in the health sector among the GMS countries will require building 
trust  and  confidence  through  more  frequent  and  focused  dialogue  and  exchange;  developing 
networks across the MOHs, public and private health institutes, and other relevant stakeholders; 
learning  from  one  another’s  experiences;  exchanging  information;  and  embarking  on  joint 
research  on  critical  regional  health issues.  Once  the  trust and  networks  are in  place,  then  the 
GMS countries can move on to more challenging regional cooperation health initiatives such as  
synchronizing disease control strategies, and setting regional standards for goods and services.

E. 

Lessons Learned 
 
47. 
Experience with regional projects is limited. As regional projects are more complex than 
national projects, there is a risk of following a vertical approach in planning regional projects that 
undermines national efforts for integration and decentralization, and may not be sustainable. On 
the  other  hand,  regional  projects  supportive  of  national  programming  can  work  as  a  catalyst 
through  exchanging  ideas,  challenging  governments  and  creating  a  favorable  climate  for 
change. Strong regional coordination and support as provided in the regional Community Action 
for the Prevention of HIV/AIDS (footnote 9) has shown to be critical in achieving project impact.  
 
48. 
The CLV countries are slow to start up new projects. Several projects took more than a 
year to get the implementation arrangements and consulting services in place.16 But after that 
initial delay, the projects usually proceed well. The proposed project will therefore make use of 
existing administrative capacity of ongoing projects (footnotes 12, 13, and 16).  
 
49. 
The  public  health  systems  in  CLV  countries  are  facing  serious  staff  and  budget 
constraints, which in turn affect the capacity of Governments to implement and sustain projects. 
Any  project  activity  should  be  included  in  the  projections  for  health  sector  spending  in  the 
coming years, and projects should undertake substantial capacity building at all levels.

Component 3: Strengthening Regional Cooperation in CDC  

64. 
The common health sector challenges facing the CLV countries present opportunities for 
intensified  or  new  forms  of  regional  cooperation.  The  cross-border  nature  of  many  diseases 
necessitates  standard  setting  and  joint  action.  Regional  cooperation  provides  opportunities  for 
learning  what  works  and  what  does  not,  provides  greater  leverage  for  support,  and  helps 
optimize the allocation of resources and scale up efforts in key areas that can generate the most 
benefits.  
 
65. 
An explicit component for regional cooperation in CDC is deemed necessary to provide 
the leverage and policy focus that specific collaboration on surveillance and disease control may 
lack,  and  facilitate  cross-border  dialogue.  Hence,  the  main  purposes  of  this  component  are  to 
enhance  regional  cooperation  in  CDC  among  the  CLV  countries  and  create  sustainable 
foundations for future cooperation. More specifically, the subsidiary objectives are: (i) increase 
capacity  for  health  system  development  in  general  and  health  policy  and  legal  frameworks  in 
particular  across  the  region;  (ii)  promote  learning,  research,  and  information  exchange  across 
the  health  sectors  of  the  three  countries;  and  (iii)  promote  coordination  in  disease  prevention 
and control across borders. 
 
66. 
Three  subcomponents  have  been  designed:  (i)  regional  coordination  for  dialogue  on 
CDC, (ii) regional operations research and institutional linkages, and (iii) project management. 
The  formulation  of  subcomponents  and  their  corresponding  activities  was  based  on  selected 
criteria,  some  of  which  are  drawn  from  the  criteria  of  the  GMS  Working  Group  on  HRD  for 
priority projects. Regional activities should (i) be of national significance to each country and be 
based on identifiable common interests and goals; (ii) create sustainable foundations (i.e., not 
be a “one-off” activity);  (iii) provide  cross-country learning and sharing; (iv) have an impact on 
inequalities within and between the countries; and (v) provide better economies of scale where 
applicable.  Overall,  regional  cooperation  should  bring  added  value  to  national  health  systems 
and RPGs for health (see also Appendix 5).  
 
67. 
In  response  to  critical  needs  in  the  health  systems  of  the  CLV  countries,  the  first 
subcomponent will promote regional coordination and peer dialogue among the CLV countries 
and other GMS countries. First, one or two regional SC meetings will be held each year during 
the  Project  to  assess  project  implementation  and  progress,  coordinate  activities,  and  identify 
key issues. The SC will also decide on joint studies. Second, technical forums will be held on 
the  following:  (i)  specific  diseases  targeted  under  the  Project,  (ii)  CDC  financing  and  health 
systems development, (iii) the targeting of vulnerable groups for health services, (iv) regulations 
and  standards  in  the  health  sector,  and  (v)  regional  surveillance  and  response  for  emerging 
diseases  like  AI.  The  main  purpose  of  these  forums  is  to  strengthen  health  systems  by  (i) 
carrying  out  dialogue  on  the  issues;  (ii)  exchanging  ideas  and  experiences  in  health  policies, 
laws,  financing  options,  and  interventions;  and  (iii)  exploring  opportunities  to  coordinate  and 
harmonize policy and legal standards.  
 
68. 
The  second  subcomponent  focuses  on  regional  operations  research  for  HIV/AIDS  and 
the development of linkages among institutions in the GMS for other types of joint research and 
demand-based  initiatives.  The  Project  will  support  a  series  of  high-quality  research  studies  on 
particular regional aspects of the HIV/AIDS’s epidemiology in the three countries by building on 
the extensive database (including baseline and final surveys, prevalence surveys, and records 
of  input/output  data)  generated  by  JFPR  9006  (footnote  9).  Key  topics  for  research  include: 
(i) emerging patterns of trafficking in women and the impact on HIV/AIDS, (ii) vulnerability and 
risk  associated  with  transport  corridors,  (iii)  road  construction  and  other  major  infrastructure

Special Features 

72. 
Evidently, the first special feature of the Project is the regional approach that it takes to 
CDC  and  health  systems  development.  Typically,  health  systems  improvement  and  CDC 
activities are conducted in national and local settings. The Project involves regional or bilateral 
initiatives  among  the  CLV  countries,  including  joint  disease  control  activities  and  forums  for 
exchanging lessons learned and reviewing needs and progress.  
 
During  the  GMS  HRD  working  group,  all  six  countries  expressed  strong  support  for  a 
73. 
regional CDC project. However, they decided that the Project would focus on the CLV countries. 
It  is  hoped  that  a  second  phase  will  include  other  GMS  countries  (PRC,  Myanmar,  and

Thailand). The Project supports the participation of these countries as observers in the regional 
SCs and as participants in regional technical forums.  
 
74. 
Another feature of the Project is its emphasis on using regional cooperation for national 
health  systems  development.  Ultimately,  national  and  local  governments  are,  by  and  large, 
responsible  for  ensuring  the  health  of  their  citizens,  and  need  to  develop  the  system  design, 
legislation,  and  resources  to  make  this  happen.  While  health  policy  and  strategies  cut  across 
borders,  health  interventions  are  largely  a  national,  if  not  local,  responsibility.  Hence,  regional 
collaboration  needs  to  strengthen  national  health  systems  to  be  relevant,  and  it  is  a  powerful 
tool  for  that  purpose,  through  such  means  as  creating  a  climate  of  constructive  learning  and 
competition among the countries. 
 
The  Project  provides  important  policy  support for  national health  systems  development 
75. 
that is in line with the current know-how on improving the effectiveness and efficiency of health 
systems.  It  focuses  on  strengthening  the  provincial  health  services  using  sound  management 
principles, and on integrating CDC to improve coverage and efficiency.  
 
76. 
Rather  than  creating  a  new  regional  institution,  the  Project  aims  to  strengthen  and 
institutionalize regional coordination in MOHs and ensure that it is provided with its own budget, 
staff, responsibilities, and authority. 
 
77. 
The Project will strengthen regional initiatives. Some of these entail obligations deriving 
from  their  membership  in  global  and  regional  organizations,  such  as  WHO  and  the  ASEAN, 
while  others  are  national  initiatives  supported  by  a  variety  of  donors.  Specifically,  the  GMS 
Governments  are  supporting  various  initiatives  in  regional  CDC  and  want  to  strengthen  their 
collaboration.  They  are  working  toward  a  comprehensive,  sustainable  system  for  regional 
collaboration  in  CDC  in  the  GMS  and  eventually  in  ASEAN.  Most  important  in  the  context  of 
control  of  emerging  diseases  is  that  WHO  will  soon  require  its  members  to  attain  the  revised 
IHR. The Project will provide important capacity building for IHR. 
 
78. 
The  Project  also  has  important  externalities  beyond  the  health  sector,  by  generating 
political  goodwill  and  cooperation  among  sectors.  This  will  further  reinforce  the  GMS  spirit  of 
peace, prosperity, and poverty reduction.

IV. 

PROJECT BENEFITS, IMPACTS, ASSUMPTIONS, AND RISKS 

104.  Project  Benefits  and  Beneficiaries.  The  Project  will  help  improve  the  health  of  the 
targeted  population  and  thereby  increase  their  productivity,  and  help  progress  toward  the 
health-related  MDGs.  The  Project  will  improve  prevention  and  control  of  communicable 
diseases,  intergovernmental  cooperation  in  containing  and  eliminating  diseases,  and  also 
contribute to strengthening national health systems.  
 
105.  Activities  under  the  Project  are  targeted  toward  the  poor  in  general  and  those  living  in 
remote locations including border areas, where many ethnic groups and the most poor reside. 
Women and children will be the major beneficiaries of these community-level interventions.   
 
106.  Analysis  of  Economic  and  Financial  Sustainability.  The  economic  benefits  of  the 
Project  will  come  from  (i)  helping  prevent  major  epidemics;  (ii) productivity  gains  from  an 
increased lifespan and reduced mortality; (iii) productivity gains from improved achievements in 
education, especially through less absenteeism and reduced dropout rates; and (iv) public and 
private savings in health expenditures, including indirect costs.  
 

 

  

 

25

107.  The Project’s recurrent costs include integrated service delivery staff costs, procurement 
of  medical  supplies,  and  ongoing  institutional  strengthening  costs,  which  together  will  account 
for  about  $1.7  million in  2009,  the  year  of  projection completion.  It  is  envisaged  that  recurrent 
costs  would  be  scaled  back  to  about  $1.1  million  in  2012  as  the  Project  demonstrates  the 
benefits  of  using  items  like  worm  tables  and  larvicides  for  dengue  and  households  purchase 
such items. The summary economic and financial analysis is in Appendix 13. 
 
108.  Environment. The Project will not have any significant adverse environmental effects. In 
general, it will finance preventive health services, which leave limited by-products, and will help 
safeguard the environment by putting in place an early warning and response system. This will 
help  reduce  the  environmental  costs  of  disease  control,  in  particular  insecticide  spraying. 
Project supervision will closely monitor the issue of medical wastes. 
  
109.  Social Analysis. The targeted provinces have a high proportion of families living below 
or  near  the  poverty  line  who  depend  on  subsistence  farming  for  their  survival,  in  particular 
among ethnic minorities. They depend heavily on the availability of a healthy labor force in the 
family.  Any  serious  disease  or  death  in  the  family  may  throw  the  family  into  even  deeper 
poverty,  malnutrition,  and  ill  health.  The  summary  poverty  reduction  and  social  strategy  is  in 
Appendix 14.  
 
110.  Gender. The Project is focusing on health problems of the poor, in particular women and 
children, and should not have any adverse social impacts for women and children. The Project 
will  mainstream  women’s  (including  ethnic  women)  specific  health  concerns  to  ensure  that 
health  services  take  into  account  their  cultural  and  biological  differences.  The  Project  also 
includes  specific  interventions  benefiting  poor  children  most,  such  as  deworming  of  school 
children.  Prevention  of  disease  and  epidemics  will  generally  help  households  improve 
productivity,  and  thereby  reduce  food  shortages.  A  gender  analysis  was  undertaken  during 
project preparation to ensure that women receive adequate support from the Project (Appendix 
15).  Based  on  this  gender  analysis,  each  coordinating  IA  will  prepare  country-specific  gender 
plans for project implementation. 
 
111.  Ethnic  Minorities.  Ethnic  minorities  constitute  a  major  proportion  of  the  population  in 
the three countries, and often reside in relatively remote hills and forests where living conditions 
are  difficult.  They  suffer  disproportionately  from  common  communicable  diseases  such  as 
malaria,  diarrheal  diseases,  and  worm  infections,  and  also  have  less  access  to  health  care 
because  of  physical,  financial,  language,  and  cultural  barriers.  The  Project  is  specifically 
targeting  ethnic  groups  in  the  selection  of  provinces,  types  of  interventions,  and  planning  and 
monitoring arrangements. The ethnic minority development plan is in Appendix 16.   
 
112.  Risks.  The  Project  has  some  technical  risks  in  the  effectiveness  of  control  measures. 
Technical  risks  will  be  mitigated  by  partnering  with  WHO,  hiring  national  consultants  for  local 
capacity  building,  and  strengthening  provincial  and  community  involvement.  Institutional 
networking and regional collaboration will also help in strengthening stakeholder involvement.  
 
113.  Previous  ADB  projects  showed  project  management  to  be  critical  to  achieving  results. 
Each coordinating IA will have a project management unit, which will be supported by existing 
project  administrative  capacity  in  MOH  in  areas  like  planning,  procurement,  financial 
management, monitoring, and reporting.   
 
114.  Regional  cooperation  requires  considerable  front-end  costs  with  low  immediate  returns 
because of an “incubation period.” However, these costs should be offset by substantial benefits 

 26 

 

from  regional  disease  control,  technology  transfer,  and  strengthened  national  commitment  for 
health  sector  development,  all  of  which  will  have  long-term  value  across  the  region.  ADB  will 
need to provide substantial support for regional cooperation and ensure that this becomes fully 
institutionalized in terms of budget, staff, responsibility, and authority in the ministries. 
 
115.  The sustainability of new services after project completion is a key risk. In Lao PDR, the 
Project will increase the total public health budget by about 4.5% as public health spending is 
currently very low. The Government of the Lao PDR is planning a substantial increase in public 
health spending over 2006–2010. The fiscal situation is expected to have improved substantially

73/1999/ND-CP  of  18  August  1999  and  10/2002/ND-CP  of  16  January  2002  to  ensure  the 
implementation  of  Resolution  05/2005/NQ-CP  of  18  April  2005  to  improve  health  sector 
financing.  Each  Government  is  committed  to  sustaining  the  capacity  for  operating  the 
surveillance and response and integrating CDC systems in the targeted provinces. Supplies of 
essential  drugs,  a  direct  pro-poor  intervention,  will  be  the  major  items  of  recurrent  costs.  The 
Project  will  help  the  Governments  plan  for  these  supplies,  and  will  also  encourage  self-
treatment where applicable and preventive health behavior to contain recurrent costs.

HEALTH SECTOR ANALYSIS 

Introduction 

 
A. 
 
1. 
The health of a population is a critical determinant of a country’s capacity for social and 
economic  development,  and  is  therefore  also  a  key  factor  in  shaping  regional  cooperation.  At 
meetings of the Greater Mekong Subregion (GMS), leaders have expressed concerns about the 
health  sector  and  identified  many  regional  threats,  as  well  as  opportunities,  that  would  greatly 
benefit  from  regional  cooperation.  The  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  accordingly  funded  a 
project preparatory technical assistance (PPTA) for the GMS Regional Communicable Diseases 
Control (CDC) Project1 to analyze the health sector and identify regional health sector priorities 
in  three  countries—Cambodia,  the  Lao  People’s  Democratic  Republic  (Lao  PDR),  and  Viet 
Nam. 
 
2. 
Newly  emerging  diseases  such  as  avian  influenza  and  severe  acute  respiratory 
syndrome  (SARS)  pose  new  threats  to  the  region’s  population  and  challenges  for  disease 
control.  Although  these  diseases  have  not  caused  major  fatalities2  compared  to  malaria, 
tuberculosis,  acute  respiratory  infections  (ARI),  diarrheal  diseases,  and  other,  more  common 
infectious  diseases,  the  evident  economic  impact  and  the  potential  for  a  regional  or  global 
pandemic  are  making  avian  influenza  (and  previously  SARS)  high  priorities  among  national 
health  systems  and  international  health  institutions.  This  is  particularly  so  because  early 
recognition  and  referral  at  the  community  level  is  required  to  avert  these  diseases  that  have 
high  case  fatality  and  potential  for  a  rapid  epidemic.  In  the  region,  community-based 
surveillance, preparedness, and response are underdeveloped.  
 
3. 
Nonetheless, it is the ordinary endemic diseases like pneumonia and diarrheal diseases 
that  exact  a  heavy  toll  on  the  population,  in  particular  children.  In  Cambodia  and  Lao  PDR, 
communicable diseases are the most common causes of morbidity and mortality. According to 
most  recent  statistics  of  the  World  Health  Organization  (WHO),  ARI,  diarrheal  diseases,  and 
malaria are  the most common causes of morbidity in Cambodia, while malaria, ARI, and road 
accidents cause the most deaths. HIV/AIDS3 is not in the top five, but may be masked by ARI, 
tuberculosis,  or  even  road  accidents.  In  Lao  PDR,  malaria,  pneumonia,  and  gastrointestinal 
problems  cause  the  most  morbidity  and  mortality.  In  Viet  Nam,  which  has  better  health 
indicators overall, pneumonia, acute pharyngitis, and ARI are the common causes of morbidity, 
while  intracranial  injury,  road  transport  accidents,  and  pneumonia  are  common  causes  of 
mortality.4 
 
4.

Even  where  sufficient  coverage  is  achieved,  it  does  not  imply  that  good  quality  care  is 
available. In fact, given human resource, financial, and supply constraints, and the general lack

7. 
Compared with typical health sector problems of management and resources, the issues 
in  CDC  are  somewhat  different  and  have  to  do  with  the  way  CDC  is  fragmented  and  donor-
driven, with limited accountability and authority at the local level.  
 
B. 
 
8. 
In  the  late  1980s,  WHO  and  partners  introduced  the  concepts  of  “primary  health  care 
(PHC)”  and  the  “district  health  system”  toward  health  for  all.  These  concepts  are  still  highly 
relevant and form the central pillars of country health policies today. However, support for PHC, 
for  a  variety  of  reasons,  was  increasingly  replaced  by  a  more  selective  approach  focusing  on 
diseases or subsectors. CDC was increasingly organized through vertical programs for quicker 
impact. The programs included the expanded program of immunization, the tuberculosis control 
program,  the  malaria  control  program,  and  the  HIV/AIDS  control  program.  There  were  also 
prominent programs for child survival, focusing on ARI and diarrheal diseases control, followed 
by  the  introduction  of  tools  for  the  Integrated  Management  of  Childhood  Illnesses  (IMCI),  and 
again, recently, a new regional strategy for child survival.   
 
9. 
The  organizational  structures  of  the  health  systems  in  the  three  countries  present  a 
major  institutional  divide  between  curative  and  preventive  services,  from  central  to  provincial

The  institutional  setup  in  the  three  countries  is  broadly  similar.  In  Cambodia,  the  CDC 
Department  has  overall  responsibility  for  surveillance,  response,  and  preparedness  through 
three  bureaus:  (i)  Bureau  of  CDC  and  Prevention,  (ii)  Bureau  of  Disease  Surveillance,  and 
(iii) Bureau  of  Quarantine.  In  addition,  there  are  national  programs  for  HIV/AIDS,  tuberculosis, 
and  leprosy,  and  for  malaria,  dengue,  and  schistosomiasis.  The  national  programs  are 
individually responsible for surveillance and control activities for these diseases. The Maternal 
and Child Health Unit is responsible for surveillance and control of cholera and other diarrheal 
diseases, ARI, and vaccine-preventable diseases (of the National Immunization Program). This 
structure  presents  challenges  for  institutional  coordination  of  activities,  including  surveillance 
and response.  
 
12. 
The  24  provincial  health  departments  support  67  operational  districts  in  implementing 
the  National  Health  Policy  and  ensure  equitable  distribution  of  resources.  The  provinces  and 
districts do not have dedicated staff for surveillance and response activities. These functions are 
usually allocated to staff in the national programs and the maternal and child health programs.

and  three  to  four  staff members  at  the  operational  district level.  The Ministry  of  Health  (MOH) 
has  created  village  health  groups  to  promote  health  in  the  villages.  However,  compared  with 
other  countries,  Cambodia  provides  modest  village  health  care  at  best.  Community 
organizations are small. There is substantial reliance on the private sector, but it is not part of 
the reporting system.  
 
13.

Sector  Support  Plan  (HSSP)  for  2003–2007,  which  provides  the  basis  for  sector-wide

Reduction Scheme. The Department of Planning and Health Information has developed the first

promoting village health support groups and health center management committees, improving 
IMCI, improving consumer confidence in health services, and improving ethical conduct.

C. 

Reasons for Regional Cooperation in CDC 

21. 
Communicable diseases do not stop at borders. HIV/AIDS, the SARS crisis in 2003, and 
more recent concerns about avian flu have highlighted the importance of regional cooperation in 
CDC.  Countries  are  responding  to  their  own  limitations  and  vulnerabilities  to  the  spread  of 
infections from outside their borders by working more closely together. The rapid identification of 
a  disease  outbreak  and  a  coordinated  regional  response  will  significantly  contain  the  adverse 
health  and  economic  effects  on  populations.  Programs  for  the  prevention  and  control  of 
communicable disease outbreaks are, therefore, regional public goods (RPGs), and not merely 
national public goods. 
 
22. 
Common health sector challenges facing Cambodia, Lao PDR, and Viet Nam give rise to 
opportunities (and demand) for new forms of regional cooperation. The cross-border nature of 
many diseases, the need for more efficient allocation of limited resources through economies of 
scale, and the necessity for joint actions to prevent or contain disease outbreaks are among the 
broad reasons for greater regional cooperation among countries in health matters. 
 
For example, people in border areas nowadays cross borders frequently to work, sell or 
23. 
buy goods, engage in road or other infrastructure development, and use the new infrastructure, 
thus  facilitating  the  spread  of  communicable  diseases  and  making  it  difficult  to  treat  infected

communities  to  communicable  diseases.  Containment  of  infected  people  is  complicated  by 
limited  access  to  treatment  in  an  area.  Common  vectors  and  environments  in  border  districts 
may  lead  to  transmission.  The  focus  of  disease  control,  therefore,  needs  to  be  geographic 
rather than being based on formal boundaries. The health officials of a country must operate in 
unaccustomed  ways.  Perhaps  most  importantly,  countries  can  learn  from  one  another  what 
works in matters ranging from the health education needs of ethnic minorities to health sector 
financing. Common standards will make it easier for countries to coordinate and exchange staff, 
information, services, and goods. Differences in health policies, such as the cost of treatment, 
and  in  the  quality  of  service  may  push  residents  of  border  areas  to  seek  treatment  in  a 
neighboring  country.  And  finally,  working  together  will  provide  important  leverage  and 
economies of scale.  
 
D. 

New International Health Regulations 

24. 
Emerging  infections such  as  SARS,  Nipah  virus  infections, Japanese  encephalitis, and 
human  cases  of  avian  influenza,  and  epidemic  diseases  such  as  meningitis,  cholera,  typhoid 
fever, and dysentery pose a growing threat to the health of the world’s populations. Their early 
recognition  is  often  difficult  and  their  containment  challenging.  Responding  appropriately  to 
these  infectious  threats  requires  better  structures,  coordination  among  health  systems,  and 
workforce development to strengthen disease control. 
 
25. 
To strengthen national and global health security, epidemics must be contained at their 
source  and  their  potential  to  spread  in  the  local  and  international  communities  must  be 
minimized. Countries need to increase their capacity for rapid detection and timely response to 
public health emergencies. They also need to enhance coordination and cooperation with one 
another in tackling cross-border diseases.  
 
The  recently  revised  Internal  Health  Regulations  (IHR)  provide  the  legal  framework  for 
26. 
actions  to  prevent  the  international  spread  of  disease.  Countries  will  be  expected  to  establish 
and maintain minimum core surveillance and response capacities to successfully implement the 
global  health  security,  epidemic  alert,  and  response  strategy.  These  requirements  entail  (i)  at 
the  community  level,  detecting  illnesses  and  deaths  above  expected  levels  and  reporting 
information to appropriate local health personnel; (ii) at the primary public health response level, 
verifying reported events, implementing immediate control measures, and reporting information 
to the national level; and (iii) at the national level, assessing all health event reports within 24 
hours  and  reporting  public  health  emergencies  of  international  concern  to  WHO.  The  revised 
IHR  provide  a  decision  instrument  to  assist  countries  in  assessing  events  and  immediately 
notifying  WHO  about  events  that  could  signify  a  “public  health  emergency  of  international 
concern.” The latter phrase is fully defined in the draft IHR. 
 
27.  WHO guidelines (available in draft form since February 2004) provide countries with the 
detailed  technical  information  and  understanding  needed  to  establish  functions  that  will  meet 
their capacity requirements. The revised IHR were endorsed by the World Health Assembly in 
May 2005, with a proposed implementation date in 2006. WHO will support countries in building 
the technical capacity to comply with the revised IHR.

Challenges in Regional Cooperation 

Cooperation in the health sector among the CLV countries is still in a nascent stage of 
30. 
development.  The  memoranda  of  understanding  for  health  sector  cooperation  are  relatively 
recent,  and  the  agreed-upon  frameworks  have  in  most  instances  not  been  followed  up  with 
sufficient action or details about how the frameworks should be implemented. One of the critical 
success  factors  in  new  formal  cooperation  arrangements  is  the  prior  existence  of  informal 
networks  across  the  participating  countries.  The  absence  of  such  networks  typically  causes  a 
lag  between  when  the  cooperative  framework  is  established  and  when  it  is  acted  on  and  the

institutions.  This  is  clearly  true  of  the  health  ministries,  laboratories,  and  institutes  in  the  CLV

technical level. Therefore, high-level political agreements to cooperate in the health sector are 
unlikely  to  bear  much  fruit  until  networks  and  linkages  develop  among  the  technical  health 
specialists. 
 
31. 
RPGs receive less attention than global and national public goods. In particular, rates of 
return on regional investments are often higher than individual country investments and reduce 
the  costs  for  smaller  economies.  Global  initiatives  prevail  over  regional  ones  despite  the 
complexities involved in implementing them worldwide, and they tend to lose focus on the “weak 
links”  (i.e.,  countries  with  limited  capacities)  that  make  global  health  initiatives  less  effective. 
Clear  gaps  in  health  RPGs  exist  within  ASEAN  and  the  GMS  countries.  There  is  no 
comprehensive  regional  health  information  system,  and  research  with  a  regional  perspective 
(e.g., on migrants and HIV/AIDS) is lacking. Another challenge to the provision of RPGs is the 
lack  of  coordination  among  external  agencies.  The  purpose  of  the  regional  strategy  is  to 
develop  a  comprehensive  framework  to  give  people  in  the  Asia-Pacific  better  protection  from 
emerging  diseases.  The  focus  will  be  on  preventing,  detecting,  and  controlling  the  emerging 
diseases  that  are  posing  new  threats  and  challenges  to  the  people  and  health  systems  in  the

6. 
Regional  and  cross-border  cooperation  in  health  matters  is  not  intended  to  replace

regional health cooperation, collaboration has been difficult to achieve even in North America.

of  a  border,  even  along  the  US-Mexico  border  with  its  high  level  of  interactions  and  shared

summarized in Table A5.1.2 A key lesson that can be derived from these barriers is that cross-
border  collaboration  in  health  must  involve  the  central,  state/provincial,  and  local  levels,  and 
both public and private sectors.

Quarantine  staff  and  other  border  health  officials  will  be  trained  in  early 
diagnosis and rapid testing of malaria and TB among migrants. 
 
Diarrheal  diseases  from  unsafe  food  are  a  major  cause  of  morbidity  in 
border  areas,  where sanitation  is  generally  poor  and  the people have  less 
knowledge  about  how  to  handle  food  properly.  Coordinated  campaigns 
among  border  communities  will  have  economies  of  scale  and  broaden 
project reach. 
 
Increased  vaccination  coverage  has  produced  a  dramatic  decline  in  the 
incidence  of  some  infectious  diseases.  To  detect,  control,  and  prevent 
infectious  diseases  that  are  vaccine-preventable,  border  regions  must 
coordinate  their  immunization  campaigns  so  as  not  to  miss  children  and 
women in remote areas or moving across borders. 
 
Reducing  tuberculosis  rates  requires  active  surveillance,  including  testing 
at-risk populations, providing curative therapy to TB patients, and ensuring 
that therapy is completed. All this is necessary to prevent drug-resistant TB, 
which is more difficult and expensive to deal with. 
 
The establishment of mobile health units in border areas could significantly 
extend  the  provision  of  health-care  services.  People  in  border  areas  are 
often located far from stationary health facilities and often cannot afford the 
costs  of  transportation  to  receive  services  or,  if  already  ill,  are  physically 
unable to make a long journey.

CLV  countries.  To  reduce  negative  outcomes  at  delivery  for  both  the 
mothers and the newborns, early start of prenatal care is important for the 
identification of health problems and risk factors.

available  across  the  border,  but  immigration,  quarantine,  and  other 
obstacles  prevent  patients  from  getting  the  care  they  need.  An  existing 
memorandum  of  understanding  between  Cambodia  and  the  Lao  People’s 
Democratic  Republic,  for  example,  calls  for  such  cooperation  in  treating 
nationals from the other side of the border, but the details that would allow

Project Beneficiaries 

 
1. 
The economic analysis of projects helps in identifying and selecting public investments 
that  will  improve  the  welfare  of  beneficiaries  and  the  country  as  a  whole.  This  appendix 
analyzes  the  economic  justification  for  the  proposed  investment  in  regional  communicable

A. 
 
2. 
The overall anticipated impact of the Greater Mekong Subregion (GMS) Regional CDC 
Project is containment of the spread of epidemic diseases at the local level and reduction of the 
burden of common endemic diseases in Cambodia, the Lao People’s Democratic Republic (Lao 
PDR),  and  Viet  Nam  by  about  15%  overall,  and  more  for  certain  specific  infections.1  This  will 
help the CLV countries progress toward their health-related Millennium Development Goals for 
2015. The expected project outcomes are (i) timely and adequate control of epidemics that are 
likely to have a major impact on the region’s public health and economy; (ii) improved coverage 
of prevention and care of communicable diseases in vulnerable populations, in particular poor 
women  and  children  living  in  border  areas;  (iii)  improved  know-how,  policies,  standards,  and 
coordination of countries to improve CDC, including HIV/AIDS2 control; and (iv) efficient project 
management.  
 
B. 
 
3. 
The  Project  has  national  benefits—resulting  from  a  reduction  in  the  macroeconomic 
impact  of  emerging  diseases  like  avian  influenza,  severe  acute  respiratory  syndrome  (SARS), 
and dengue fever, and in the incidence of diseases such as helminthiasis, digestive diseases, 
HIV/AIDS, measles, and other diseases in selected vulnerable populations. The CLV countries 
have  nearly  100  million  people,  about  17  million  of  whom  live  below  the  international  poverty 
line  of  $1  per  day  (purchasing  power  parity).  Many  of  these  people  are  ethnic  minorities  and 
women  and  children  living  in  remote  border  areas,  where  the  prevalence  of  communicable 
disease  is  disproportionately  high.  The  proposed  project  interventions  have  been  designed  to 
specifically address these groups by developing capacity, improving access to health facilities, 
and providing equipment and drugs in priority areas of need. 
 
C. 
 
The  economic  and  equity-based  rationales  for  investing  in  CDC  are  extremely  high. 
4. 
There  are  strong  linkages  between  health  and  the  burden  of  infectious  diseases  and  labor 
productivity.  A  range  of  macroeconomic  studies  suggest  that  improved  health  is  empirically 
related to economic growth3 (see review in Macroeconomics and Health: Investing in Health for 
Economic  Development,  J.  Sachs  and  others),  and  specifically  in  relation  to  CDC,  research 
indicates  that  high  prevalence  of  diseases  such  as  malaria  or  HIV/AIDS  is  associated  with 
significantly  lower  rates  of  economic  growth.  For  example,  the  impact  of  HIV/AIDS  on  the 
annual rate of economic growth ranges from 0% to 2% (Bloom and Mahal 1997, Bonnel 2000).4

B.  Poverty Analysis  
Cambodia. In 1993–1999, Cambodia experienced a reduction in poverty  from 39% to 36%. Estimates show that about 
15–20% of the population lives in extreme poverty. Poverty in Cambodia is concentrated in rural and remote areas. The 
poverty  rate  in  urban  areas  is  estimated  at  29.7%  compared  with  40.1%  in  rural  areas.  Poverty  is  due  to  a  number  of 
factors,  including  the  limited  sources  of  economic  growth,  exclusion  of  the  poor  from  the  mainstream  economy,  limited 
access to and poor quality of social services, unavailability of credit, and lack of productive assets and resources (e.g., 
land,  forestry,  and  fisheries).  A  number  of  indigenous  hill  tribe  groups,  primarily  located  in  Ratanakiri  and  Mondulkiri 
provinces, are among the poorest and most vulnerable segments of Cambodia’s population. 
 
Lao PDR. Poverty incidence fell from 45% in 1992–1993 to 30% by 2002–2003. The sharp reduction in poverty incidence 
was  associated  with  consecutive  years  of  strong  economic  growth,  achievement  of  rice  self-sufficiency,  and  increased 
cross-border trade. However, poverty levels differ between urban and rural areas, and regionally across the country. For 
instance,  the  northern  part  of  the  Lao  PDR  has  a  poverty  incidence  of  about  52%.  By  focusing  primarily  on  the  poor 
northern  provinces  and  the  GMS  East–West  Economic  Corridor,  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  emphasizes 
development opportunities from cross-border trade and movement and the importance of the private sector along border 
areas and key economic corridors. 
 
Viet Nam. Data from the 2002 Multipurpose Household Survey confirmed a continuing decline in the incidence of poverty, 
from 58% in 1993 to 29% in 2002. The decline in the last 5 years was not uniform across the country: poverty dropped 
most sharply in the Mekong Delta area (from 37% in 1998 to 23%) but remained highest in the Central Highlands (about 
52%). The underdeveloped state of infrastructure in poor regions causes the gap between them and other regions in the 
country  to  widen.  High  and  stable  economic  growth  in  the  past  several  years  has  been  a  major  contributor  to  poverty 
reduction, but the benefits from economic growth have not been evenly distributed. 
 
The Project will focus on surveillance and response and control of selected diseases, which will mainly benefit the poor 
and other vulnerable groups. These groups suffer from a higher burden of disease, particularly communicable diseases, 
and have limited access to both public and private health services. At least 47% of the project benefits will accrue to the 
population  living  below  the  poverty  line.  Ethnic  minorities  in  the  three  countries  will  benefit  from  the  Project's  focus  on 
remote  areas  and  its  commitment  to  train  local  health  workers  and  community  volunteers.  Targeted  surveillance  and 
response,  along  with  targeted  control  of  endemic  diseases,  will  reduce  the  burden  of  communicable  diseases  and 
generate economic benefits as follows: (i) increased health awareness will lead to improvements in health, which in turn 
will  significantly  decrease  out-of-pocket  health  expenditures;  (ii)  improved  health  services  for  infants  and  children  will 
reduce the number of sick children, thereby improving school attendance and overall physical and cognitive development; 
and  (iii)  strengthened  disease  surveillance  and  response  systems  will  help  avoid  costs  associated  with  outbreaks  (e.g., 
the avian influenza outbreak is estimated to have cost the Mekong countries about $563 million since 2003).

Strategy to maximize impacts on women: 
Women  in  Cambodia,  Lao  PDR,  and  Viet  Nam,  especially  ethnic  minority  women,  remain  particularly  vulnerable  to 
poverty. Cambodia has among the lowest levels of gender equity in Asia as measured by the gender-related development 
index (0.557) and the gender empowerment index (0.364). Rural and ethnic minority women in these countries carry out 
more than half of total agricultural production, as well as the additional workload around the home. Women workers earn 
considerably  less  than  male  workers,  and  women  consistently  consume  fewer  calories  than  males,  as  indicated  by  the 
higher malnutrition, mortality, and morbidity rates for girls and women than for males.  
 
Maternal  and  child  mortality  in  the  region  is  high,  but  most  of  the  primary  causes  are  preventable.  Acute  respiratory 
infections, infectious diarrhea, and parasitic diseases are significant causes of morbidity and mortality among women and 
children.  A  lack  of  awareness  of  CDC  and  low-quality  health  services  disproportionately  affect  the  poor  and  vulnerable 
groups, including ethnic minorities. Poor women are particularly vulnerable to sexual exploitation.  
 
A gender analysis was conducted during project preparation to ensure that gender concerns in CDC were identified and 
addressed  in  the  overall  project  design.  A  gender  action  plan  (GAP)  with  monitoring  indicators  has  been  developed  to 
ensure that gender-related health issues were integrated into the implementation of the regional project. Country-specific

country. National social development specialists will be recruited to assist the project management unit in each country in

groups  compose  about  32%  of  the  Lao  PDR  population.  Larger  ethnic  groups  include  the 
Hmong,  Khmu,  Phutai,  Kor,  and  Katu.  In  Viet  Nam,  there  are  officially  54  ethnic  groups 
belonging to different family and language groups composing 14% of the total population. They 
are  spread  out  over  45  provinces  and  live  mainly  in  mountainous  areas.  About  31  ethnic 
minority  groups  live  mainly  in  the  Northern  Uplands  and  about  19  ethnic  minority  groups  live 
mainly in the Central Highlands.  
 
B. 
 
In  the  three  countries,  the  infant  and  child  mortality  rates  and  maternal  mortality  ratios 
3. 
are generally higher in the provinces with a high proportion of ethnic minorities. Ethnic minorities 
in all three countries suffer more often from common infectious diseases than the majority ethnic 
groups.  These  diseases  include  diarrheal  diseases,  acute  respiratory  infections,  tuberculosis, 
malaria,  measles,  and  other  infections  often  associated  with  poor  living  conditions  and 
malnutrition.  Minority  peoples  are  also  at  special  risk  of 
the  human 
immunodeficiency virus (HIV) because of lack of access to education, poverty, lack of culturally 
appropriate  information  in  their  own  languages,  cultural  and  social  breakdown  within  some 
communities,  nontraditional  drug  use,  and  a  relatively  high  involvement  in  the  sex  trade  and 
other  forms  of  exploited  labor.  However,  they  are  at  less  risk  of  dengue  and  other  emerging 
diseases, which are more common in the lowlands (Appendix 3). 
 
Cambodia’s northeastern provinces have a higher incidence of infectious diseases than 
4. 
other provinces. In Lao PDR, where more than 90% of births occur at home in the presence of a 
relative or a traditional birth attendant, about 60% of all maternal deaths occur during childbirth. 
In Viet Nam, the infant mortality rate has dropped, from 90 per 1,000 live births in 1980 to 36 per 
1,000  live  births  in  1996  (Appendix  3).  But  the  rate  is  higher  in  the  Northern  Uplands  (52  per 
1,000 live births in 1996) and Central Highlands (55 per 1,000 live births in 1996). Poverty and 
imbalanced economic growth contribute to poor nutrition and high child mortality and morbidity 
rates.  Similarly,  maternal  mortality  has  been  reported  at  almost  160  per  100,000  live  births  in 
rural  areas  and  nearly  four  times  higher  in  remote  mountainous  areas.  Common  causes  of 
maternal  death  are  hemorrhage,  pre-eclampsia,  malaria,  sepsis  resulting  from  abortion,  and 
obstructed labor causing the uterus to rupture.

Legal Frameworks and Principles 

C. 
 
5. 
Hygienic  living  conditions  and  basic  preventive  and  curative  care  can  address  most 
infections,  malnutrition,  and  maternal  complications.  However,  ethnic  minorities  have  less 
physical, social, and financial access to health care because of their isolation. Prenatal care and 
services to handle complicated births are often not available in remote rural settings. Rural and 
ethnic  minority  women  rarely  have  any  form  of  antenatal  care,  in  part  because  of  cultural 
inhibitions  and  language  barriers.  Ethnic  minority  women  often  do  not  use  health  services 
because of their (perceived) high cost. Many are very poor and lack cash.  
 
D. 
 
Each Government has a clear legal framework and set of principles in support of ethnic 
6. 
minorities.  Cambodia’s  Rectangular  Strategy 
(2004–2008),  Second  Socio-Economic 
Development  Plan  (2001–2005),  and  National  Poverty  Reduction  Strategy  (2003–2005) 
emphasize  equity  and  social justice  for  everyone,  including  ethnic  minorities.  In  the  Lao  PDR, 
recent laws and decisions reflect ethnic concerns in the development process in all sectors. The 
National  Socio-Economic  Development  Plan  (2001–2005)  has  adopted  as  its  objective  the 
alleviation of poverty for ethnic groups in remote areas. The Constitution highlights the right of 
ethnic groups to protect, preserve, and promote their customs, and prohibits acts of division and 
discrimination  (Article  8).  Viet  Nam’s  Comprehensive  Poverty  Reduction  and  Growth  Strategy 
(2001–2010)  deals  directly  with  issues  of  gender  and  ethnic  minorities.  The  Government 
recognizes  ethnic  minorities  as  poor  and  underprivileged  groups.  Current  government  policies 
and programs aim to enhance the health status of ethnic minorities. The Central Party Executive 
Committee  Directive  N06-CT/TW  (2002)  provides  guidelines  for  the  Ministry  of  Health  to 
formulate  polices  with  priority  given  to  people  in  remote  and  mountainous  areas,  especially 
ethnic minorities.  
 
E. 
 
7. 
The Project has three components: (i) strengthening national surveillance and response 
systems;  (ii)  improving  provincial  CDC  for  the  poor  and  vulnerable,  in  particular  women, 
children, and ethnic minorities; and (iii) strengthening regional cooperation in CDC.  
 
8. 
Three  subcomponents  of  the  Project  provide  special  focus  on  vulnerable  groups 
including  ethnic  minorities:  (i)  a  community-based  surveillance  and  response  system  that  will 
aim to reach remote living populations, to achieve timely control of epidemics like malaria and 
measles, but also avian influenza, encephalitis, and other epidemics; (ii) improved CDC in these 
populations  as  a  result  of  better  access  to  promotive,  preventive,  and  basic  curative 
interventions  through  village  health  workers;  and  (iii)  HIV/AIDS  control  through  behavioral 
change and communication among high-risk groups, including ethnic minorities, in “hot spots.”   
 
F. 
 
ADB  policy  aims  to  protect  ethnic  minorities  from  the  adverse  effects  of  development 
9. 
and  to  ensure  that  ethnic  minorities  benefit  from  development  projects  and  programs.  The 
Project will create favorable conditions for better surveillance and response, improved access to 
communicable  disease  services,  and  more  effective  subregional  collaboration  for  better 
response to and preparedness for pandemic outbreaks. The EMDP for the Project is based on 
government guidelines in the countries and ADB policy on indigenous peoples. It proposes two

10. 
Village-Based Health Care. To give remote communities better access to health care, 
the  Project  will  improve  village-based  health  care  by  training  village  workers  from  ethnic 
minorities.  These  workers  will  carry  out  health  promotion  and  prevention  campaigns  including 
those for avian influenza and HIV/AIDS, provide basic treatment, and improve preparedness for 
common  emergencies.  For  each  ethnic  group,  specific  cultural  issues  will  be  identified  at  the 
local level and incorporated in the local design to make services more acceptable. Materials and 
training programs will be designed to take into account the level of education and language of 
the  target  groups.  Revolving  funds  for  drugs  will  be  set  up  at  the  village  level,  where  this  is 
feasible. These funds could also be used to improve water and sanitation coverage and other 
locally identified activities for disease prevention and control.  
 
11. 
Community-Based  Action  for  CDC.  The  Project  will  also  explore  community-
mobilization for CDC. It will develop a participation strategy appropriate for ethnic minorities to 
improve surveillance and response at the community level, and to improve control of endemic 
diseases, by mobilizing leadership and mass organization, and providing demonstration models.  
 
G.

promote  progress  toward  the  health-related  Millennium  Development  Goals,  and  intensify 
intergovernmental cooperation to contain diseases and strengthen national health systems. The 
Project design fully integrates the health needs of vulnerable groups, including ethnic minorities 
at  the  community  level.  Specific  activities  focus  on  primary  health  care  in  remote  areas,  and 
these consist of community-based interventions.

14. 
The  implementation  arrangements  and  estimated  costs  of  the  EMDP  have  been 
integrated  into  the  overall  arrangements  and  total  budget  of  the  Project.  The  project 
management unit in each country will supervise the implementation of the EMDP, and national 
institutes and provincial preventive health offices involved in the Project will implement the plan. 
Three national social development specialists, one for each country, will be hired for 18 person-
months each during the Project. Each social development specialist will help develop country-
specific implementation guidelines to integrate the specific measures set out in the EMDP. The 
specialist  will  work  with  the  regional  international  technical  experts  to  adapt  and  integrate  the 
EMDP into project activities for each country.  Measures and targets will be integrated into the 
assessment of preventive health needs, the preparation of provincial health plans, and training 
activities (including the training of trainers) in each province.
